title.narrative: ACCESS:EDUCATION

description.narrative: By 2024, children and young people, especially the most disadvantaged benefit from quality learning and acquire skills to develop to their full potential., which contributes to Access To Quality Learning Opportunities, Access To Quality Learning Opportunities (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: National evaluation capacity development

participating-org.narrative: GENERAL DIRECTORATE OF EDUCATION IN KIRKUK

System strengthening - Evidence based education sector planning
Technical assistance - Equitable access to quality education

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2024, children and young people, especially the most disadvantaged benefit from quality learning and acquire skills to developto their full potential.

description.narrative: Regardless of the challenges imposed by COVID-19, UNICEF and partners supported 8,185 children (4,055 girls) to access ECE, 32,637 out of school children (15,312 girls) to access primary/basic education and 6,044 adolescent girls to continue lower secondary education. Also, 433,087 children in humanitarian situation benefited from a range of interventions, including establishment of prefab schools, provision of prefabricated classrooms, Back-to-Learning (B2L) campaigns, provision of school supplies and teaching learning materials. In response to COVID-related school closure, 4.17 million children and adolescents were supported using alternative delivery mechanisms such as education television, online portals and self-learning materials. | Status:Partially met | As-of Date:16/01/2022
